title: China plans evacuations as Typhoon Ragasa barrels through Philippines
summary: China plans to evacuate close to 400,00 people from Shenzhen as the typhoon makes landfall in the northern Philippines.

title: UN marks 80 years amid Gaza genocide and global crises
summary: Marking 80 years of the UN, Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said its principles are “under assault as never before”.

title: The terrifying spectre of an internet shutdown in Afghanistan
summary: A partial shutdown of fibre-optic internet has spread fear. Afghans do not want to be cut off from the world.

title: US targets Brazilian justice’s wife with sanctions; will revoke more visas
summary: Six officials will see their visas revoked following the sentencing of Trump ally Jair Bolsonaro.

title: US public opinion on Israel is changing, US policy will have to as well
summary: Unconditional US support for Israel will come to an end, but this policy shift may take years.

title: Cyberattack on European airports caused by ransomware, EU finds
summary: Since Friday, Europe's busiest airports have faced significant disruptions after hackers hit automated check-in systems.

title: Israeli attack kills four members of a family in Lebanon
summary: An Israeli drone attack killed four members of a family in Lebanon, including the father and three of his children.

title: Barred from Eurovision, Russia holds its own rival song contest
summary: Barred from Eurovision, Russia held its own rival song contest called ‘Intervision’ featuring singers from 23 countries.

title: Christian Horner leaves Red Bull after agreeing exit from F1 team
summary: The former Red Bull team principal has reportedly agreed a $107m payoff deal with the Formula One team.

title: Hardline lawmakers demand nuclear bomb as Iran braces for UN sanctions
summary: Seventy members of parliament sign a letter calling for a 'change in the defence doctrine' of the nation.

title: How Trump’s visa fees could reshape working in the US
summary: Donald Trump just made hiring some foreign workers much more expensive, as H-1B visa fees jump to $100,000 annually.

title: H-1B fee hike: Who’s gaining from these visas – Indian IT or US firms?
summary: Indian companies were the biggest beneficiaries for years. But that's changed; US firms now dominate visa recipients.

title: “Ils meurent sous nos yeux” : le cri d’alarme du directeur de l’hôpital Al-Shifa à Gaza-ville
summary: Depuis la mise hors service d’autres établissements de soins de la ville de Gaza à cause des bombardements israéliens la semaine dernière, l’hôpital d’Al-Shifa fait face à un flot ininterrompu de blessés. Contacté par la rédaction des Observateurs, le directeur de l'hôpital, Mohammed Abou Salmiya, témoigne d’une situation ingérable.

title: En Égypte, le militant emblématique Alaa Abdel-Fattah gracié
summary: Le militant égypto-britannique Alaa Abdel-Fattah, figure emblématique du soulèvement de 2011 en Égypte, a été gracié, lundi, par le président Abdel Fattah al-Sissi, a annoncé Al-Qahera News, un média proche des autorités égyptiennes.

title: Paris: Les drapeaux palestinien et israélien projetés sur la tour Eiffel
summary: La projection sur un grand écran de la tour Eiffel, à Paris, qui n’avait pas été annoncée, a débuté à 21 heures et s’est poursuivie jusqu’à 23h45.

title: Reconnaissance de la Palestine : "Enfin, mais peut-être trop tard ?"
summary: A la Une de la presse, ce lundi 22 septembre, la reconnaissance attendue, aujourd’hui, de la Palestine par la France à l’Assemblée générale des Nations unies. Neuf pays occidentaux ont décidé de lui emboîter le pas.

title: Reconnaître l'État de Palestine, "un geste très important" pour les étudiants palestiniens
summary: À la veille de la reconnaissance de l’État de Palestine par la France, de nombreux Palestiniens se réjouissent de la décision française mais doutent qu’elle puisse faire évoluer favorablement leurs conditions de vie. Reportage à l’université Bir Zeit de Ramallah, ville où siège l’Autorité palestinienne en Cisjordanie.

title: En direct : la France et d'autres pays s'apprêtent à reconnaître l'État de Palestine à l'ONU
summary: Après le Royaume-Uni, le Canada, l'Australie et le Portugal, c'est au tour de la France et d'autres pays de reconnaître, lundi à l'ONU, l'État de Palestine, lors d'un sommet organisé par Paris et Riyad sur la solution à deux États. Emmanuel Macron formalisera cette reconnaissance lors d'un discours dans la soirée, tandis que le prince héritier saoudien Mohammed ben Salmane devrait intervenir en visioconférence. Suivez notre direct.

title: En Cisjordanie occupée, les colons veulent rendre impossible la création d'un État palestinien
summary: Depuis plusieurs semaines, le gouvernement israélien multiplie les annonces d’extension de colonies existantes ou de légalisation de colonies sauvages en Cisjordanie occupée. La reconnaissance annoncée d’un État palestinien par la France et d’autres pays occidentaux accélère l'occupation israélienne de la Cisjordanie. Pour la rendre irréversible ? Reportage.

title: Reconnaissance de l'État de Palestine par le Royaume-Uni, le Canada, l'Australie et le Portugal
summary: Le Portugal reconnaît un Etat palestinien, a déclaré dimanche le ministre des Affaires étrangères Paulo Rangel, emboîtant le pas au Royaume-Uni, au Canada et à l'Australie. Une reconnaissance qui intervient avant un sommet coprésidé par la France et l'Arabie saoudite portant sur l'avenir de la solution à deux États, à la veille de l'Assemblée générale de l'ONU.

title: Reconnaissance de la Palestine : pas d'ambassade sans libération des otages, dit Emmanuel Macron
summary: Malgré de fortes pressions des États-Unis et d'Israël, et avant la grand-messe de l'Assemblée générale de l'ONU, le Royaume-Uni, le Canada, l'Australie puis le Portugal ont reconnu l'État palestinien dimanche. Israël a condamné ces décisions, qualifiées de "mouvements pour la galerie" par Washington. Voici le fil du 21 septembre 2025.

title: Le Royaume-Uni s'apprête à reconnaître l'État palestinien dimanche
summary: Ignorant les pressions diplomatiques des États-Unis et d'Israël, le Royaume-Uni va reconnaître officiellement dimanche l'État de Palestine. Constatant une dégradation de la situation à Gaza, le Premier ministre Keir Starmer doit annoncer cette décision dans la journée, indiquent plusieurs médias britanniques.

title: Henry Laurens : "Il ne peut pas y avoir d'occupation heureuse, c'est elle qui engendre la violence"
summary: Une nouvelle étape a été franchie cette semaine dans la guerre qu'Israël livre au Hamas dans la bande de Gaza. La phase principale de son offensive sur la ville de Gaza a démarré, précédée par un déluge de feu nocturne qui a terrifié ses habitants, dont une grande partie a fui direction des zones qui n'ont d'humanitaire que le nom. Le jour même du lancement de cette offensive, une commission d'enquête internationale indépendante de l'ONU a accusé Israël de commettre un "génocide" à Gaza, car remplissant 4 des 5 critères du génocide tel que défini par la Convention de 1948.

title: Reconnaissance de la Palestine : le monde ne doit pas être "intimidé" par Israël, estime l'ONU
summary: "Nous ne devons pas nous sentir intimidés par le risque de représailles" israéliennes contre les reconnaissances de l'État palestinien, a plaidé vendredi le secrétaire général de l'ONU Antonio Guterres, à quelques jours de l'ouverture de l'Assemblée générale de l'organisation. De son côté, l'armée israélienne se prépare samedi à frapper avec une "force sans précédent" la ville de Gaza. Le fil du 20 septembre 2025.

title: En direct, guerre en Ukraine : à la suite de l’incursion d’avions russes dans plusieurs pays, les Etats-Unis promettent de défendre « chaque centimètre du territoire de l’OTAN »
summary: « Comme nous l’avons dit il y a neuf jours, les Etats-Unis soutiennent leurs alliés de l’OTAN face à ces violations de l’espace aérien », a déclaré, lundi, Mike Waltz, le nouvel ambassadeur américain à l’Organisation des Nations unies, lors d’un Conseil de sécurité. Les représentants des 32 pays de l’Organisatin du traité de l’Atlantique Nord (OTAN) doivent se réunir mardi matin à Bruxelles.

title: En Italie, des manifestations en solidarité avec Gaza rassemblent des dizaines de milliers de personnes
summary: Des dizaines de milliers de personnes ont manifesté, lundi, à travers toute l’Italie pour « dénoncer le génocide à Gaza », lors d’une journée de mobilisation marquée par des grèves et des blocages à l’appel de plusieurs syndicats reprenant le slogan du mouvement français Bloquons tout.

title: « La crise mondiale de l’information représente une grave menace pour la prospérité économique et le progrès humain »
summary: Un collectif de onze économistes, parmi lesquels Philippe Aghion et Joseph Stiglitz, appelle, dans une tribune au « Monde », les gouvernements internationaux à reconnaître et à défendre la valeur des médias d’intérêt général à travers une série de mesures.

title: TikTok US utilisera une copie de l’algorithme de la plateforme chinoise qui sera gérée par Oracle, annonce le gouvernement américain
summary: Aux Etats-Unis, la gestion des données de TikTok sera désormais confiée à la société américaine Oracle, coupant tout accès à la maison mère, ByteDance, et répondant ainsi aux inquiétudes du Congrès sur la sécurité nationale.

title: Jordi Savall, chef d’orchestre : « Si nous n’arrivons pas à arrêter ce qui se passe à Gaza, chacun de nous sera moralement responsable »
summary: Dans une tribune au « Monde », le musicien catalan encourage les artistes et les membres de la société civile à se mobiliser pour le retour des otages détenus par le Hamas et pour la fin de la guerre.

title: Plus de 50 mairies hissent le drapeau palestinien, le jour où la France doit reconnaître l’Etat de Palestine
summary: Lyon, Nantes, Rennes, Saint-Denis et Stains font partie des 52 municipalités ayant choisi de hisser le drapeau palestinien, malgré la consigne d’interdiction donnée par le ministère de l’intérieur.

title: En Suède, la majorité des travailleurs thaïlandais pour la cueillette des baies sont privés de visa
summary: Après une série de scandales impliquant des entrepreneurs suédois accusés d’exploiter les cueilleurs venus de Thaïlande, ceux-ci n’ont pas été autorisés à venir pour la saison 2025. Résultat : les prix de la myrtille et de l’airelle flambent.

title: Aux Philippines, des manifestations contre la corruption massive dans les travaux publics
summary: Le président, Ferdinand « Bongbong » Marcos, qui a pris les devants en dénonçant, à la fin de juillet, la gabegie généralisée qui gangrène les institutions, risque de devoir gérer les retombées des enquêtes dans son propre camp.

title: Le militant Alaa Abd El-Fattah, figure de la révolution égyptienne, gracié par le président Al-Sissi après des années de détention
summary: La libération d’Alaa Abd El-Fattah intervient après des années de mobilisation internationale et de grèves de la faim.

title: L’italien ENI veut acheter plus de 1 milliard de dollars d’électricité issue de la fusion nucléaire à une start-up américaine
summary: L’entreprise CFS a annoncé la conclusion d’un contrat avec l’énergéticien, pour une fourniture d’électrons au cours de de la décennie 2030, produits par une centrale mettant en œuvre la fusion nucléaire, une technologie qui n’a jamais produit d’énergie.

title: En direct, Gaza : au moins 29 Palestiniens ont été tués par des tirs et des bombardements israéliens dans la bande de Gaza depuis le début de la journée, selon WAFa
summary: WAFa ajoute que la situation est critique, plusieurs infrastructures médicales ayant été mises hors service. Emmanuel Macron doit reconnaître officiellement l’Etat de Palestine dans un discours à l’ONU, prévu ce soir.

title: En Italie, la crainte d’une contagion du mouvement antivax, galvanisé par la figure de Robert F. Kennedy
summary: Depuis la nomination de Robert F. Kennedy Jr à la tête du ministère de la santé américain, la communauté scientifique redoute une propagation des idées vaccinosceptiques au reste du monde. Cette influence s’est notamment manifestée en Italie.

title: Jubilant Palestinians raise flag outside London embassy after UK recognition
summary:
Jubilant Palestinians raise flag outside London embassy after UK recognition

Jubilant Palestinians held a flag-raising ceremony on Monday outside what is now their country's embassy to the United Kingdom, a day after Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced his long-awaited recognition of a Palestinian state.

Attended by hundreds of officials, including Foreign Office minister Hamish Falconer, Scotland's First Minister John Swinney, and several Labour and independent MPs, the presumptive Palestinian ambassador to the UK, Husam Zomlot, said the UK's recognition was about "righting historic wrongs".

"In the same capital of the Balfour Declaration, after more than a century of ongoing denial, dispossession and erasure, the UK government has finally taken the long overdue step of recognising the state of Palestine," Zomlot said.

Holding up a plaque, to cheers from the crowd, he said: "Very soon, pending some legal work, some bureaucratic work… this plaque, which reads 'The Embassy of the State of Palestine'... will be placed right behind me on this building."

He said the moment was "not only about Palestine, it is also about Britain and the British government's solemn responsibility.

Read more: Jubilant Palestinians raise flag outside London embassy after UK recognition

title: Jubilant Palestinians raise flag outside London embassy after UK recognition
summary:
Jubilant Palestinians raise flag outside London embassy after UK recognition

Submitted by MEE staff on Mon, 09/22/2025 - 10:39
Palestinian Ambassador Husam Zomlot said UK recognition was crucial in 'ending the denial of the Palestinian people's inalienable right to freedom and self-determination'
Husam Zomlot, the presumptive Palestinian ambassador to the UK, holds up a plaque which reads "Embassy of the State of Palestine" during a ceremony in London on 22 September 2025 (Toby Melville/Reuters)
Off

Jubilant Palestinians held a flag-raising ceremony on Monday outside what is now their country's embassy to the United Kingdom, a day after Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced his long-awaited recognition of a Palestinian state.

Attended by hundreds of officials, including Foreign Office minister Hamish Falconer, Scotland's First Minister John Swinney, and several Labour and independent MPs, the presumptive Palestinian ambassador to the UK, Husam Zomlot, said the UK's recognition was about "righting historic wrongs".

"In the same capital of the Balfour Declaration, after more than a century of ongoing denial, dispossession and erasure, the UK government has finally taken the long overdue step of recognising the state of Palestine," Zomlot said.

Holding up a plaque, to cheers from the crowd, he said: "Very soon, pending some legal work, some bureaucratic work… this plaque, which reads 'The Embassy of the State of Palestine'... will be placed right behind me on this building."

He said the moment was "not only about Palestine, it is also about Britain and the British government's solemn responsibility.

"It is about ending the denial of the Palestinian people's inalienable right to freedom and self-determination and it is an acknowledgement of a historic injustice."

 
 
 
 
View this post on Instagram
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

A post shared by Middle East Eye (@middleeasteye)

The ceremony came a day after Starmer announced the UK’s decision to formally recognise a Palestinian state, more than 100 years after the Balfour Declaration backed "the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people".

Canada, Australia, and Portugal also officially recognised Palestinian statehood on Sunday, two days before the start of the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA).

France, Belgium, Luxembourg, San Marino and Malta are expected to recognise a Palestinian state later on Monday, in an attempt to pile pressure on Israel as it presses on with its ethnic cleansing campaign in Gaza despite international outrage.

'This recognition comes at a time of unimaginable pain and suffering as a genocide is being waged against us - and allowed to continue with impunity'

- Husam Zomlot, Palestinian Mission to UK

Israel launched its long-threatened ground offensive on Gaza City last week, on the same day a UN inquiry declared that it was committing genocide in the Palestinian territory.

Zomlot reminded the international community "that this recognition comes at a time of unimaginable pain and suffering as a genocide is being waged against us – a genocide that is still being denied and allowed to continue with impunity."

He continued: "It comes as our people in Gaza are being starved, bombed, and buried under the rubble of their homes; as our people in the West Bank are being ethnically cleansed, brutalised by daily state-sponsored terrorism, land theft and suffocating oppression."

Zomlot said the recognition was occurring "as the humanity of Palestinian people is still questioned, our lives still treated as disposable and our basic freedoms still denied."

More than 238,000 Palestinians have either been killed, wounded or are missing since Israel launched its genocidal war on Gaza in October 2023. 

Last week a UN commission of inquiry found that Israel had committed genocide in Gaza since October 2023.

Recent reports, based on Israeli military intelligence data, indicate that more than 80 percent of those killed in the enclave until May of this year were civilians.

Since US President Donald Trump entered office, Israel has repeatedly rejected ceasefire agreements that would see the release of all captives held in Gaza in exchange for ending the war. It has instead vowed to continue the war until Hamas is defeated.

Palestine state

title: Singapore to impose sanctions on leaders of Israeli settler groups
summary:
Singapore to impose sanctions on leaders of Israeli settler groups

Singapore's foreign minister on Monday said that the country will impose "targeted sanctions" on leaders of Israeli settler groups and would recognise a Palestinian state, Reuters news agency has reported. 

"We call on the Israeli government to cease settlement construction and expansion," Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan said, speaking in parliament, adding that the E1 settlement project would lead to fragmenting the West Bank.

"We oppose ongoing attempts to create new facts on the ground which undermine the prospects for a two-state solution," he said. 

Balakrishnan said Singapore would recognise a Palestinian state and that the nation is waiting for an "appropriate constellation" of factors.

“Ultimately, to resolve this longstanding conflict in a comprehensive, just and durable manner, there needs to be a negotiated settlement which results in two states, one Israeli [and] one Palestinian, with their peoples living alongside each other in peace, security and dignity,” he added.

title: ‘Unwilling and unable’: Half of Gaza City refuses to flee as Israeli attacks intensify
summary:
‘Unwilling and unable’: Half of Gaza City refuses to flee as Israeli attacks intensify

Dima Abuaita packed her most precious belongings, along with clothes and mattresses, and placed them by the door of her family’s home in the central Gaza City neighbourhood of Rimal.

For more than a week, she has been searching for affordable transportation to flee to the southern Gaza Strip amid relentless Israeli attacks.

“It’s not that I refuse to save my life and my children’s - it’s that I don’t have a fortune to keep us safe,” Abuaita told Middle East Eye.

“I need around 5,000 shekels ($1,500) just to move my belongings to the central or southern parts of the strip, another 2,000 shekels ($600) for a tent, and then a monthly rent for the land to set it up. I simply cannot afford all that.”

Last month, Israel declared it was going to fully occupy Gaza City and intended to force all Palestinians there and elsewhere in the north - around 1.2 million people altogether - towards the south.

Relentless Israeli attacks since 11 August have forced half of the city’s population out, leaving around half a million remaining as paratroopers backed by tanks push a ground offensive into various neighbourhoods.

Meanwhile, booby-trapped robots and explosive-packed, remote-controlled vehicles have been used to level the city.

Read more: Half of Gaza City refuses to flee as Israeli attacks intensify

title: Israeli strike kills father and three children in south Lebanon massacre
summary:
Israeli strike kills father and three children in south Lebanon massacre

Israeli drone strikes have killed five people, including a father and his three children, in the southern Lebanese town of Bint Jbeil, in what has been denounced as “a massacre”.

In the late afternoon on Sunday, two consecutive missiles were fired, with one targeting a motorcycle, and another hitting a car carrying a family of six.

The victims were identified as Shadi Sharara and three of his children - Celine, Hadi, and Silane - all reportedly American citizens.

Their mother Amani and sister Aseel were wounded. The driver of the motorcycle was identified as Mohammed Mroueh.

Lebanese Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri said in a statement that the family held US citizenship. The US State Department, however, said there are indications they were not American citizens.

President Joseph Aoun condemned the strike and urged the international community to pressure Israel to respect the ceasefire reached with Hezbollah in late November.

Read more: Israeli strike kills father and three children in south Lebanon massacre

title: The UK government has recognised Palestine - real action must follow
summary:
The UK government has recognised Palestine - real action must follow

Submitted by Afzal Khan on Mon, 09/22/2025 - 12:21
If left at that, recognition risks ringing hollow as it alone will not change the reality on the ground for Palestinians
After the UK recognition of Palestine, a flag is raised at Palestinian Mission to the UK in London on 22 September, 2025 (Matthew Chattle/Reuters)
On

The UK government’s recognition of the Palestinian state marks a welcome and historic milestone.

While the UK has taken a substantial step by reaffirming the country’s commitment to a two-state solution in the region and to upholding international law, it is crucial that we do not allow these commitments to remain in name only.

I and countless others have campaigned for this for decades.

Recent polls show nearly half of Britons support recognising Palestinian statehood, and, in July, over 220 MPs from across the political spectrum signed an open letter urging the government to act.

After decades of Palestinian displacement, dispossession and occupation, recognition is a long overdue acknowledgement of their right to self-determination. It will crucially provide Palestinians with a measure of political agency at a time when they are being systematically stripped of their rights and especially when Israel is committing a genocide against them in Gaza.

Recognition strengthens negotiations, giving Britain the credibility to press for accountability for war crimes, enforce aid access, and demand a return to meaningful talks.

It sends a clear message that international law cannot be suspended at will, and that the rights of Palestinians are not dependent on the goodwill of their occupier.  

Diplomatic weight

While 147 countries already recognise Palestine, the decisions by the UK, France, and Canada represent the first time that any G7 countries have taken this step. That France and the UK are permanent members of the UN Security Council adds further diplomatic weight.

UK: Why recognising a Palestinian state is not enough
Read More »

Yet recognition, if left at that, risks ringing hollow as recognition alone will not change the reality on the ground for Palestinians. 

Under the current Israeli government, Palestinians in Gaza continue to face a genocidal war with no ceasefire in sight as Israeli ministers discuss plans to annex parts of the strip and the West Bank. 

The occupation of the West Bank is intensifying with unabated settler violence, forced displacement and settlement expansion plans that could make any future Palestinian state virtually impossible.

Last year, Israel’s Knesset passed a resolution that overwhelmingly rejected the any steps towards Palestinian statehood. 

In these circumstances, it is clear, recognition must be the beginning, not the end of the UK’s work on Palestine. Recognition must come with concrete demands to protect Palestinian rights and revive a credible prospect of two states living side by side in peace and security. 

This must include a full application of international law, beginning with pressure to end the genocide in Gaza. Recognising Palestinian sovereignty also requires us to strongly reject Israeli settlements and annexation while revisiting our trading relationship with Israel. 

This must include banning all goods from settlements and reassessing arms export licences. 

A key juncture 

This is a chance to redefine the peace process as conversations can move away from debating whether Palestine can and deserves to become a state.

Our action over the coming weeks will define whether this moment becomes a turning point

With statehood as a given, discussions can now focus on how a functioning state can be constituted with borders, governance, territorial rights, and security.

Given Britain’s role in the region’s history and commitments in 1917 with the Balfour Declaration, we have a particular responsibility to uphold "civil and religious rights" of Palestine’s "existing non-Jewish communities".

More than a century later, that second promise remains unfulfilled. 

And now, we are again at a key juncture. While the UK’s recognition of a Palestinian state has been long overdue, we now have the opportunity to go further and reclaim our moral standing, legal responsibility and diplomatic leadership in regards to our actions in the region.

Britain has the opportunity to lead a coordinated recognition by democracies that could create space for accountability, reconstruction and a secure, internationally backed roadmap toward a two-state settlement.

Our action over the coming weeks will define whether this moment becomes a turning point.

The views expressed in this article belong to the author and do not necessarily reflect the editorial policy of Middle East Eye.

Palestine state
Opinion

title: Israeli attacks force children's hospital in Gaza out of service
summary:
Israeli attacks force children's hospital in Gaza out of service

The Ministry of Health in Gaza reported on Monday that both the al-Rantisi Children's Hospital and the Eye Hospital were rendered out of service, following continued targeting by Israeli forces.

Israeli forces have killed at least 37 Palestinians in Gaza since dawn on Monday, including 30 in Gaza City. 

Last week, the ministry said the Israeli army struck Al-Rantisi Children’s Hospital three times while 80 patients were inside.

Israel has killed at least 65,300 Palestinians since it started its genocidal war in October 2023. 

The United Nations' International Commission of Inquiry on the Occupied Palestinian Territory has concluded that Israel is committing genocide in Gaza. Israel has also imposed an aid blockade in the region, leading to the death of at least 442 Palestinians, including 147 children. 

More than half a million people in Gaza are experiencing famine, marked by widespread starvation, according to the UN's Integrated Food Security Phase Classification.

title: Israeli forces kill 37 Palestinians since dawn on Monday
summary:
Israeli forces kill 37 Palestinians since dawn on Monday

Israeli forces have killed at least 37 Palestinians in Gaza since dawn on Monday, Al Jazeera Arabic has reported, quoting hospital sources. 

At least 61 Palestinians were killed in Israeli attacks across Gaza in the past 24 hours, the territory’s health ministry said.

Another 220 people were wounded in the same period.

Since Israel began its war on Gaza on 7 October 2023, the ministry reported, at least 65,344 people have been killed and 166,795 wounded.

title: Tens of thousands join pro-Palestinian protests, blockades and strikes in Italy
summary:
Tens of thousands join pro-Palestinian protests, blockades and strikes in Italy

Tens of thousands of people protested on Monday across Italy as part of a day of action to denounce the Israeli genocide in Gaza, with blockades, strikes and marches.

The demonstrations came on the same day as France and other countries prepared to recognise a Palestinian state at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, following recognition by the UK, Australia and Canada on Sunday.

Italy's right-wing government under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has said it will not recognise a Palestinian state for now.

In Rome, around 20,000 people gathered in front of the main Termini train station, according to local police, many of them students, shouting "Free Palestine" and holding up Palestinian flags.

In the northern city of Milan, where organisers said 50,000 people turned out, protesters burned a US flag, an AFP reporter said.

Some demonstrators confronted anti-riot police at Milan's central train station, with police throwing teargas and protestors launching projectiles and smashing windows, an AFP photographer reported.

In Bologna, more than 10,000 took to the streets, according to local police, with a group of demonstrators blocking the motorway before being dispersed by water cannons.

Protests also took place in Turin, Florence, Naples and Sicily, while in Genoa and Livorno, dock workers blockaded port entrances, according to Italian media.

The USB union organised a 24-hour national strike to demand that the government break off relations with Israel in solidarity with Palestinians.

Local buses and the metro service were disrupted in Rome, while national train operators also warned of delays and cancellations.

- Reporting by AFP

title: ‘Unwilling and unable’: Half of Gaza City refuses to flee as Israeli attacks intensify
summary:
‘Unwilling and unable’: Half of Gaza City refuses to flee as Israeli attacks intensify

Submitted by Maha Hussaini on Mon, 09/22/2025 - 15:13
Around half a million Palestinian civilians are facing down the Israeli offensive, some trapped by exorbitant costs, others fearing they will never be allowed to return
Anguished Palestinian resident Nidal Daloul pictured during the rescue of his daughter Noor after an Israeli strike damaged their residential building in Gaza City, 22 September 2025 (Reuters/Ebrahim Hajjaj)
Off

Dima Abuaita packed her most precious belongings, along with clothes and mattresses, and placed them by the door of her family’s home in the central Gaza City neighbourhood of Rimal.

For more than a week, she has been searching for affordable transportation to flee to the southern Gaza Strip amid relentless Israeli attacks.

“It’s not that I refuse to save my life and my children’s - it’s that I don’t have a fortune to keep us safe,” Abuaita told Middle East Eye.

“I need around 5,000 shekels ($1,500) just to move my belongings to the central or southern parts of the strip, another 2,000 shekels ($600) for a tent, and then a monthly rent for the land to set it up. I simply cannot afford all that.”

Last month, Israel declared it was going to fully occupy Gaza City and intended to force all Palestinians there and elsewhere in the north - around 1.2 million people altogether - towards the south.

Relentless Israeli attacks since 11 August have forced half of the city’s population out, leaving around half a million remaining as paratroopers backed by tanks push a ground offensive into various neighbourhoods.

Meanwhile, booby-trapped robots and explosive-packed, remote-controlled vehicles have been used to level the city.

“Every day, the Israeli occupation detonates dozens of explosive-laden vehicles in neighbourhoods that are only around 10 minutes away from where I stay. And I feel them approaching day after day, but where would I go?” Abuaita said.

“I have already left my home in the Tal al-Hawa neighbourhood and took only a few of my belongings with me. I couldn’t carry more, and it was the harshest situation anyone could go through because you have to choose between what you need to survive and what you want to keep as a memory with you.”

While many Palestinians like Abuaita have not fled Gaza City due to the exorbitant costs and lack of transportation, others refuse to leave their homes, believing they would not be allowed to return.

How Israel is using robots, exploding vehicles and paratroopers to erase Gaza City
Read More »

Hala Rohme, originally a resident of Sheikh Radwan neighbourhood north of Gaza City, says she will be moving from one place to another within her hometown but never to the south.

Most residents of the city and northern Gaza were forced out in the genocide’s earliest months, but returned during a ceasefire earlier this year.

Now, Israeli officials seem intent on fully depopulating the area and erasing all Palestinian life there. 

The experience of the 1948 Nakba, when 750,000 Palestinians were permanently forced from their homes during the creation of Israel, means many believe there will be no way back for them if they leave now.

Besides, Rohme notes, when Israel is bombing tents in so-called Israeli-designated “safe zones” or cars of displaced people fleeing Gaza City, “it is not worth it to move from one deadly place to another”.

“I left my home around a week ago under devastating bombardment. We felt that the ceiling was going to fall on us. So we came to my in-laws’ home in the Old City,” said Rohme, who has never left the city during the war.

“We don’t want to leave because we know that if we did, we would never be able to return.”

‘Leave or be killed’

In late August, Israeli Defence Minister Israel Katz warned that Gaza City "will become Rafah and Beit Hanoun" if Hamas doesn't surrender, referring to two Gazan towns that have been almost completely destroyed by the Israeli military.

While Israeli tanks have advanced into the northern and eastern parts of the city, the remaining central and western areas remain under intense bombardment, including air strikes, artillery shelling and heavy gunfire.

'These robots are the nightmare of this war. They have the capacity to destroy entire neighbourhoods at once'

- Hala Rohme, resident

In one incident, a relative of Rohme was killed after an Israeli explosive-laden vehicle detonated in a nearby neighbourhood.

“My cousin’s husband from the Haddad family remained in his home in Tal al-Hawa after my cousin fled with her children to another area. There were no tanks, and the booby-trapped vehicles had not reached his area yet, and he never thought the explosions’ effect would reach him,” Rohme said.

“A few days ago, the house collapsed on his head after an explosive-laden vehicle was detonated nearby. He was killed.”

Last week, Israeli news outlet Walla reported that the military had stationed an “unprecedented” number of explosive-laden, remote-controlled vehicles to be detonated in urban areas in Gaza City.

The remotely detonated vehicles are originally aged armoured personnel carriers (APCs), converted into “mega-explosives” instead of being scrapped. The practice is referred to by the Israeli military as “suicide APCs”.

“These robots are the nightmare of this war. They have the capacity to destroy entire neighbourhoods at once, and the shrapnel has reached us multiple times, even though we are relatively far from the explosions. This is a policy of leave or be killed,” Rohme said.

On Sunday, Israeli army spokesperson Avichay Adraee said in a post on X that the 36th Division began entering Gaza City as part of “Operation Gideon’s Chariots II”, as the offensive has been dubbed, following two weeks of preparations and strikes.

It follows “Operation Gideon’s Chariots I”, which was launched in May and involved extensive land, air and sea operations that captured 65 percent of the Gaza Strip by early August.

However, key objectives, including the complete defeat of Hamas, the release of captives, and the relocation of civilians to the south, were not achieved.

Operation Gideon Chariots II focuses specifically on seizing control of Gaza City and represents a continuation of the previous campaign, intensifying attacks and driving mass displacement of the population.

Israel's genocide in Gaza has already killed more than 65,000 Palestinians in two years.

“Since they intensified the attacks, they have used every means to force us to leave the city. But we are unwilling and unable to do so,” Rohme concluded.

“Many of us, including my family and I, would rather die in Gaza than be killed by the same Israeli attacks in other parts of the strip.”

Israel's genocide in Gaza
Gaza City, occupied Palestine

title: Israeli strike kills father and three children in south Lebanon massacre
summary:
Israeli strike kills father and three children in south Lebanon massacre

Submitted by MEE staff on Mon, 09/22/2025 - 15:24
A drone missile targeted a car carrying a family of six in the town of Bint Jbeil
Amani Bazzi, a woman who was severely wounded by an Israeli drone strike the previous day in Bint Jbeil in southern Lebanon, shows pictures of her killed children on a phone as she rests at a hospital in Tebnine on 22 September 2025 (AFP)
Off

Israeli drone strikes have killed five people, including a father and his three children, in the southern Lebanese town of Bint Jbeil, in what has been denounced as “a massacre”.

In the late afternoon on Sunday, two consecutive missiles were fired, with one targeting a motorcycle, and another hitting a car carrying a family of six.

The victims were identified as Shadi Sharara and three of his children - Celine, Hadi, and Silane - all reportedly American citizens.

Their mother Amani and sister Aseel were wounded. The driver of the motorcycle was identified as Mohammed Mroueh.

Lebanese Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri said in a statement that the family held US citizenship. The US State Department, however, said there are indications they were not American citizens.

President Joseph Aoun condemned the strike and urged the international community to pressure Israel to respect the ceasefire reached with Hezbollah in late November.

“As we are in New York to discuss matters of peace and human rights, Israel continues its ongoing violations of international resolutions,” Aoun said in a statement on X. 

He accused Israel of “committing a new massacre in Bint Jbeil”. The president is in New York to attend the UN General Assembly.

Despite the truce, the Israeli military has continued to strike what it claims are Hezbollah positions in southern Lebanon, while frequently violating Lebanese airspace and maintaining its occupation of areas in the south.

Israel has stepped up both the number and frequency of its strikes this week.

According to a tally by Lebanese newspaper L’Orient Today, at least 308 people have been killed in Lebanon since the ceasefire took effect.

On Sunday evening, the Israeli army said it “regrets the injury of civilians” in the Bint Jbeil strike, which it claimed - without providing evidence - was aimed at a Hezbollah member.

Speaking to L'Orient Today, the president of Bint Jbeil municipal council, Mohammad Bazzi, called the attack a "massacre of civilians", adding that the bodies of the victims had been "mutilated and scattered".

The Lebanese army said the strikes took Israeli violations of the ceasefire to 4,500 since November.

Israel's war on Lebanon

title: Global reactions pour in as UK, Australia and Canada recognise Palestinian state
summary:
Global reactions pour in as UK, Australia and Canada recognise Palestinian state

More than 100 years after the Balfour Declaration backed “the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people”, the UK, along with Canada, Australia and Portugal officially announced their recognition of a Palestinian state on Sunday. 

France is expected to imminently follow suit.

Expectedly, this historical injunction has drawn fierce criticism from the Israeli government. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed that the establishment of a Palestinian state “will not happen”, adding that Israel’s response to the moves would come after he returned to Israel from his visit to the United States.

Speaking to BBC Radio 4 Today programme on Monday, Israeli government spokesperson David Mencer said "the Jewish community will never forgive Labour for this betrayal".

As the announcements trickled in over recent days, online social media users expressed different views.

A wave of voices dismissed the move as “performative recognition” unlikely to make any change to stop the ongoing genocide in Gaza and annexation of the occupied West Bank.

"Recognition of a state that doesn’t exist and not the genocide befalling the people of the non-existent state is a cover for actually doing something of consequence," said Palestinian writer Yara Hawari on X.

Read more: Global reactions pour in as UK, Australia and Canada recognise Palestinian state
